centralQuestion: Is redistributive taxation a solution to inequality?

reasons.description: Progressive taxes and transfers directly narrow the gap between pre‑tax and post‑tax incomes, lowering measured inequality.

sources.title: Brookings Institution: "Closing the racial wealth gap requires heavy, progressive taxation of wealth"

reasons.description: Revenue from redistributive taxes can fund social investments—such as child‑tax credits, education and health care—that reduce inequality of opportunity.

sources.title: Center for American Progress: "Progressive Principles for the 2025 Tax Debate: Having No Deal Is Better Than Having a Bad Deal"
IMF: "Redistribution, Inequality, and Growth" (Staff Discussion Note SDN/14/02)

reasons.description: Redistributive taxation curbs extreme wealth concentration, promoting fairness and social cohesion.

sources.title: Financial Times: "Meet the insurgent economists promoting a global wealth tax"
Reuters: "Majority of Americans favor wealth tax on very rich: Reuters/Ipsos poll"

reasons.description: Evidence from cross‑country and macro studies finds that well‑designed redistribution can be growth‑neutral or even pro‑growth, challenging the idea that equity and efficiency inevitably trade off.

sources.title: IMF: "Redistribution, Inequality, and Growth" (Staff Discussion Note SDN/14/02)
Brookings Institution: "A significant increase in the top income tax rate wouldn’t substantially alter income inequality"

objections.description: Higher marginal rates can reduce incentives to work, save and invest, potentially slowing economic growth.

sources.title: Financial Times: "How squeezing the rich through tax may backfire"
Bloomberg News: "Income Inequality Isn't the Problem. Uneven Growth Is."

objections.description: Complex redistributive taxes invite avoidance strategies and costly litigation, undermining their effectiveness.

sources.title: Reuters: "Mamdani's 'Millionaire Tax' and Other Financial Fallacies"

objections.description: Wealth‑tax experiments abroad show limited revenue and significant economic drag, suggesting the policy may be ineffective in practice.

sources.title: Hoover Institution: "The Wealth Tax Is A Poor Idea"

objections.description: Some analysts argue that recent declines in measured inequality stem from broader economic factors, implying redistribution is not the main lever needed.

sources.title: Financial Times: "UK inequality is getting worse, right? But what if it isn't?"

research.title: “Redistribution, Inequality, and Growth” – IMF Staff Discussion Note SDN/14/02
research.description: Analyzes panel data from 150 countries and concludes that redistribution through taxes and transfers is generally neutral or beneficial for medium‑term growth.

research.title: “Taxation and the Superrich” – Annual Review of Economics
research.description: Surveys optimal‑tax theory and empirical evidence on taxing top earners, highlighting behavioral responses and equity‑efficiency trade‑offs.

research.title: “Redistribution for Realists” – Yale Law School Public Law & Legal Theory Paper
research.description: Argues that relying solely on tax‑and‑transfer systems is often politically infeasible, proposing complementary regulatory tools for redistribution.

research.title: “Constrained Income Redistribution and Inequality” – University of Chicago Law & Economics Working Paper
research.description: Explores how political‑economy constraints limit redistributive taxation and may even lead to upward redistribution.

research.title: “Income Redistribution across OECD Countries” – OECD Economic Policy Paper No. 23
research.description: Documents a long‑run decline in the redistributive power of taxes and transfers across advanced economies and discusses policy options to reverse the trend.
